Mr. Morgan embodied the spirit of our great state‚Äîmaking things and innovating right here in Ohio.

Despite the discrimination he endured, he put his own life on the line to save his fellow Clevelanders, and improved safety for people around the world with his creations. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FLU600aXEAY_QTM.png

Despite his heroism, it took years for the city to recognize his crucial role in the rescue.

Even when orders for his life-saving smoke hoods came pouring in from fire departments across the country, many canceled their purchases when they realized the inventor was a Black man. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FLU6DzSXwAIm-l7.png

In 1916, Cleveland workers drilling a tunnel under Lake Erie became trapped in toxic fumes following a huge gas explosion.

After two previous failed rescue attempts, Mr. Morgan and his brother stepped in, using his gas masks to rescue two workers and recover four bodies. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FLU5UWIWYAIpdRk.png

Words alone cannot deliver the solutions owed to our nation‚Äôs heroes. We must seize the opportunity at hand to advance legislation that will bring us one step closer to connecting all generations of veterans with the care they need and have earned.
